The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5046/Egypt/Politics-/Protesters-plan-Coptic-mass-on-Martyrs-Sunday.aspx|title=Protesters plan Coptic mass on 'Martyrs' Sunday'|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/6/pray_quddas.aspx?ref=extraclip|title=ØµÙØ§Ø© ÙÙØºØ§Ø¦Ø¨ ÙØªØ±Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ¨Ø·ÙØ© Ø¨ÙÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ± ÙÙ (Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡)|publisher=Masrawy|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5046/Egypt/Politics-/Protesters-plan-Coptic-mass-on-Martyrs-Sunday.aspx|title=Protesters plan Coptic mass on 'Martyrs' Sunday'|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/6/pray_quddas.aspx?ref=extraclip|title=ØµÙØ§Ø© ÙÙØºØ§Ø¦Ø¨ ÙØªØ±Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ¨Ø·ÙØ© Ø¨ÙÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ± ÙÙ (Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡)|publisher=Masrawy|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>

During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/05/live-blog-feb-6-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 6 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Copts praying in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|Copts leading the crowd in prayer in Tahrir Square.]]
[[File:Copts praying in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|Copts leading the crowd in prayer in Tahrir Square.]]
â
Egyptian Christians held mass in the morning in Tahrir Square to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Crowds in Tahrir Square chanted "We are one, we are one" ahead of prayers held at noon for those killed during the protests.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> <!--notable or WP:TRIVIA-->In the midst of all of this, a young couple decided to get married. They planned to spend their honeymoon in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=In Egypt, a wedding amid the protests: 'Life shouldn't stop'|title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Washington Post|date=2011-02-07|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the train station of El Ramel.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Several thousand anti-government protesters also continued calling for the Mubarak's resignation in Mansoura.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
Egyptian Christians held mass in the morning in Tahrir Square to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Crowds in Tahrir Square chanted "We are one, we are one" ahead of prayers held at noon for those killed during the protests.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb"/> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> <!--notable or WP:TRIVIA-->In the midst of all of this, a young couple decided to get married. They planned to spend their honeymoon in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=In Egypt, a wedding amid the protests: 'Life shouldn't stop'|title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Washington Post|date=2011-02-07|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the train station of El Ramel.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb"/> Several thousand anti-government protesters also continued calling for the Mubarak's resignation in Mansoura.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb"/>
Journalists continued to be targets of the ruling regime. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
Journalists continued to be targets of the ruling regime. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
